title: OP Jaisha:Eating Mud To Survive, Walking Miles To Sell Milk And Winning Asian Games Medals
text:
There are stories of athletes who have battled life to get to where they are but if one stands out among them it is that of OP Jaisha. She holds the current record in the marathon which she clocked in 2:34:43 at the 2015 World Championships. It bettered her own record of 2:37:29 earlier that year.

But the journey was not so easy to begin with. Jaisha came from humble beginnings and was plagued by health problems and her childhood was in poverty. From the age of 5 she fought to survive and overcame the odds. She walked miles to sell milk, at times due to lack of food, she even ate mud to survive.

PTI

Rice water was a luxury and she had to walk 2 km to school everyday. At that point nobody would have thought that she would shine as an athlete. But it was after attending a sports festival that things started to take off.

In her first ever race, she won barefoot and beat the national school champion by over 100m. But more was to come. When she was in Assumption College, Jaisha ruled the roost at the 2005 University Games with gold medals in 1,500m, 5,000m and 10,000m.

The national camp followed and in 2006 a bronze medal at the Asian Games in 5000m proved she was ready for the big leagues. In 2008, she broke the national record in 3000 metres steeplechase with a time of 10:03.05 in the 50th National Inter-State Athletics Championships.

2014 saw her win bronze at the 1500m in the Asian Games. Despite a less than impressive performance at the 2016 Olympics, her legacy as an athlete has been set. She fought life and won. Her battles off the track made her a better competitor off it. That has always been Jaisha's story. One where she took on adversity and won.
